column2: TRUTH AND FALSEHOOD
column3: TRUTH AND FALSEHOOD

column2: Our knowledge of truths, unlike our knowledge of things, has an opposite, namely _error_.
column3: Our knowledge of truths, unlike our knowledge of things, has an opposite, namely underscore error underscore.

column2: So far as things are concerned, we may know them or not know them, but there is no positive state of mind which can be described as erroneous knowledge of things, so long, at any rate, as we confine ourselves to knowledge by acquaintance.
column3: So far as things are concerned, we may know them or not know them, but there is no positive state of mind which can be described as erroneous knowledge of things, so long, at any rate, as we confine ourselves to knowledge by acquaintance.

column2: Whatever we are acquainted with must be something; we may draw wrong inferences from our acquaintance, but the acquaintance itself cannot be deceptive.
column3: Whatever we are acquainted with must be something; we may draw wrong inferences from our acquaintance, but the acquaintance itself cannot be deceptive.

column2: Thus there is no dualism as regards acquaintance.
column3: Thus there is no dualism as regards acquaintance.

column2: But as regards knowledge of truths, there is a dualism.
column3: But as regards knowledge of truths, there is a dualism.

column2: We may believe what is false as well as what is true.
column3: We may believe what is false as well as what is true.

column2: We know that on very many subjects different people hold different and incompatible opinions: hence some beliefs must be erroneous.
column3: We know that on very many subjects different people hold different and incompatible opinions: hence some beliefs must be erroneous.

column2: Since erroneous beliefs are often held just as strongly as true beliefs, it becomes a difficult question how they are to be distinguished from true beliefs.
column3: Since erroneous beliefs are often held just as strongly as true beliefs, it becomes a difficult question how they are to be distinguished from true beliefs.

column2: How are we to know, in a given case, that our belief is not erroneous?
column3: How are we to know, in a given case, that our belief is not erroneous?

column2: This is a question of the very greatest difficulty, to which no completely satisfactory answer is possible.
column3: This is a question of the very greatest difficulty, to which no completely satisfactory answer is possible.

column2: There is, however, a preliminary question which is rather less difficult, and that is: What do we _mean_ by truth and falsehood?
column3: There is, however, a preliminary question which is rather less difficult, and that is: What do we underscore mean underscore by truth and falsehood?

column2: It is this preliminary question which is to be considered in this chapter.
column3: It is this preliminary question which is to be considered in this chapter.

column2: In this chapter we are not asking how we can know whether a belief is true or false: we are asking what is meant by the question whether a belief is true or false.
column3: In this chapter we are not asking how we can know whether a belief is true or false: we are asking what is meant by the question whether a belief is true or false.

column2: It is to be hoped that a clear answer to this question may help us to obtain an answer to the question what beliefs are true, but for the present we ask only 'What is truth?' and 'What is falsehood?' not 'What beliefs are true?' and 'What beliefs are false?' It is very important to keep these different questions entirely separate, since any confusion between them is sure to produce an answer which is not really applicable to either.
column3: It is to be hoped that a clear answer to this question may help us to obtain an answer to the question what beliefs are true, but for the present we ask only 'What is truth?' and 'What is falsehood?' not 'What beliefs are true?' and 'What beliefs are false?' It is very important to keep these different questions entirely separate, since any confusion between them is sure to produce an answer which is not really applicable to either.

column2: There are three points to observe in the attempt to discover the nature of truth, three requisites which any theory must fulfil.
column3: There are three points to observe in the attempt to discover the nature of truth, three requisites which any theory must fulfil.

column2: (1) Our theory of truth must be such as to admit of its opposite, falsehood.
column3: (one) Our theory of truth must be such as to admit of its opposite, falsehood.

column2: A good many philosophers have failed adequately to satisfy this condition: they have constructed theories according to which all our thinking ought to have been true, and have then had the greatest difficulty in finding a place for falsehood.
column3: A good many philosophers have failed adequately to satisfy this condition: they have constructed theories according to which all our thinking ought to have been true, and have then had the greatest difficulty in finding a place for falsehood.

column2: In this respect our theory of belief must differ from our theory of acquaintance, since in the case of acquaintance it was not necessary to take account of any opposite.
column3: In this respect our theory of belief must differ from our theory of acquaintance, since in the case of acquaintance it was not necessary to take account of any opposite.

column2: (2) It seems fairly evident that if there were no beliefs there could be no falsehood, and no truth either, in the sense in which truth is correlative to falsehood.
column3: (two) It seems fairly evident that if there were no beliefs there could be no falsehood, and no truth either, in the sense in which truth is correlative to falsehood.

column2: If we imagine a world of mere matter, there would be no room for falsehood in such a world, and although it would contain what may be called 'facts', it would not contain any truths, in the sense in which truths are things of the same kind as falsehoods. In fact, truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs and statements: hence a world of mere matter, since it would contain no beliefs or statements, would also contain no truth or falsehood.
column3: If we imagine a world of mere matter, there would be no room for falsehood in such a world, and although it would contain what may be called 'facts', it would not contain any truths, in the sense in which truths are things of the same kind as falsehoods. In fact, truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs and statements: hence a world of mere matter, since it would contain no beliefs or statements, would also contain no truth or falsehood.

column2: (3) But, as against what we have just said, it is to be observed that the truth or falsehood of a belief always depends upon something which lies outside the belief itself.
column3: (three) But, as against what we have just said, it is to be observed that the truth or falsehood of a belief always depends upon something which lies outside the belief itself.

column2: If I believe that Charles I died on the scaffold, I believe truly, not because of any intrinsic quality of my belief, which could be discovered by merely examining the belief, but because of an historical event which happened two and a half centuries ago.
column3: If I believe that Charles the first died on the scaffold, I believe truly, not because of any intrinsic quality of my belief, which could be discovered by merely examining the belief, but because of an historical event which happened two and a half centuries ago.

column2: If I believe that Charles I died in his bed, I believe falsely: no degree of vividness in my belief, or of care in arriving at it, prevents it from being false, again because of what happened long ago, and not because of any intrinsic property of my belief.
column3: If I believe that Charles the first died in his bed, I believe falsely: no degree of vividness in my belief, or of care in arriving at it, prevents it from being false, again because of what happened long ago, and not because of any intrinsic property of my belief.

column2: Hence, although truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs, they are properties dependent upon the relations of the beliefs to other things, not upon any internal quality of the beliefs.
column3: Hence, although truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs, they are properties dependent upon the relations of the beliefs to other things, not upon any internal quality of the beliefs.

column2: The third of the above requisites leads us to adopt the view--which has on the whole been commonest among philosophers--that truth consists in some form of correspondence between belief and fact.
column3: The third of the above requisites leads us to adopt the view-which has on the whole been commonest among philosophers-that truth consists in some form of correspondence between belief and fact.

column2: It is, however, by no means an easy matter to discover a form of correspondence to which there are no irrefutable objections.
column3: It is, however, by no means an easy matter to discover a form of correspondence to which there are no irrefutable objections.

column2: By this partly--and partly by the feeling that, if truth consists in a correspondence of thought with something outside thought, thought can never know when truth has been attained--many philosophers have been led to try to find some definition of truth which shall not consist in relation to something wholly outside belief.
column3: By this partly-and partly by the feeling that, if truth consists in a correspondence of thought with something outside thought, thought can never know when truth has been attained-many philosophers have been led to try to find some definition of truth which shall not consist in relation to something wholly outside belief.

column2: The most important attempt at a definition of this sort is the theory that truth consists in _coherence_.
column3: The most important attempt at a definition of this sort is the theory that truth consists in underscore coherence underscore.

column2: It is said that the mark of falsehood is failure to cohere in the body of our beliefs, and that it is the essence of a truth to form part of the completely rounded system which is The Truth.
column3: It is said that the mark of falsehood is failure to cohere in the body of our beliefs, and that it is the essence of a truth to form part of the completely rounded system which is The Truth.

column2: There is, however, a great difficulty in this view, or rather two great difficulties.
column3: There is, however, a great difficulty in this view, or rather two great difficulties.

column2: The first is that there is no reason to suppose that only _one_ coherent body of beliefs is possible.
column3: The first is that there is no reason to suppose that only underscore one underscore coherent body of beliefs is possible.

column2: It may be that, with sufficient imagination, a novelist might invent a past for the world that would perfectly fit on to what we know, and yet be quite different from the real past.
column3: It may be that, with sufficient imagination, a novelist might invent a past for the world that would perfectly fit on to what we know, and yet be quite different from the real past.

column2: In more scientific matters, it is certain that there are often two or more hypotheses which account for all the known facts on some subject, and although, in such cases, men of science endeavour to find facts which will rule out all the hypotheses except one, there is no reason why they should always succeed.

column2: In philosophy, again, it seems not uncommon for two rival hypotheses to be both able to account for all the facts.
column3: In philosophy, again, it seems not uncommon for two rival hypotheses to be both able to account for all the facts.

column2: Thus, for example, it is possible that life is one long dream, and that the outer world has only that degree of reality that the objects of dreams have; but although such a view does not seem inconsistent with known facts, there is no reason to prefer it to the common-sense view, according to which other people and things do really exist.

column2: Thus coherence as the definition of truth fails because there is no proof that there can be only one coherent system.

column2: The other objection to this definition of truth is that it assumes the meaning of 'coherence' known, whereas, in fact, 'coherence' presupposes the truth of the laws of logic.

column2: Two propositions are coherent when both may be true, and are incoherent when one at least must be false.
column3: Two propositions are coherent when both may be true, and are incoherent when one at least must be false.

column2: Now in order to know whether two propositions can both be true, we must know such truths as the law of contradiction.

column2: For example, the two propositions, 'this tree is a beech' and 'this tree is not a beech', are not coherent, because of the law of contradiction.
column3: For example, the two propositions, 'this tree is a beech' and 'this tree is not a beech', are not coherent, because of the law of contradiction.

column2: But if the law of contradiction itself were subjected to the test of coherence, we should find that, if we choose to suppose it false, nothing will any longer be incoherent with anything else.
column3: But if the law of contradiction itself were subjected to the test of coherence, we should find that, if we choose to suppose it false, nothing will any longer be incoherent with anything else.

column2: Thus the laws of logic supply the skeleton or framework within which the test of coherence applies, and they themselves cannot be established by this test.
column3: Thus the laws of logic supply the skeleton or framework within which the test of coherence applies, and they themselves cannot be established by this test.

column2: For the above two reasons, coherence cannot be accepted as giving the _meaning_ of truth, though it is often a most important _test_ of truth after a certain amount of truth has become known.

column2: In accordance with our three requisites, we have to seek a theory of truth which (1) allows truth to have an opposite, namely falsehood, (2) makes truth a property of beliefs, but (3) makes it a property wholly dependent upon the relation of the beliefs to outside things.

column2: The necessity of allowing for falsehood makes it impossible to regard belief as a relation of the mind to a single object, which could be said to be what is believed.

column2: It is common to think of relations as though they always held between two terms, but in fact this is not always the case.

column2: Some relations demand three terms, some four, and so on.

column2: So long as only two terms come in, the relation 'between' is impossible: three terms are the smallest number that render it possible.

column2: York is between London and Edinburgh; but if London and Edinburgh were the only places in the world, there could be nothing which was between one place and another.

column2: Such a proposition as 'A wishes B to promote C's marriage with D' involves a relation of four terms; that is to say, A and B and C and D all come in, and the relation involved cannot be expressed otherwise than in a form involving all four.

column2: The relation involved in _judging_ or _believing_ must, if falsehood is to be duly allowed for, be taken to be a relation between several terms, not between two.

column3: This constitutes the definition of truth and falsehood that we were in search of.

column2: Judging or believing is a certain complex unity of which a mind is a constituent; if the remaining constituents, taken in the order which they have in the belief, form a complex unity, then the belief is true; if not, it is false.
column3: Judging or believing is a certain complex unity of which a mind is a constituent; if the remaining constituents, taken in the order which they have in the belief, form a complex unity, then the belief is true; if not, it is false.

column2: Thus although truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs, yet they are in a sense extrinsic properties, for the condition of the truth of a belief is something not involving beliefs, or (in general) any mind at all, but only the _objects_ of the belief.
column3: Thus although truth and falsehood are properties of beliefs, yet they are in a sense extrinsic properties, for the condition of the truth of a belief is something not involving beliefs, or (in general) any mind at all, but only the underscore objects underscore of the belief.

column2: A mind, which believes, believes truly when there is a _corresponding_ complex not involving the mind, but only its objects.
column3: A mind, which believes, believes truly when there is a underscore corresponding underscore complex not involving the mind, but only its objects.

column2: This correspondence ensures truth, and its absence entails falsehood.
column3: This correspondence ensures truth, and its absence entails falsehood.

column2: Hence we account simultaneously for the two facts that beliefs (a) depend on minds for their _existence_, (b) do not depend on minds for their _truth_.
column3: Hence we account simultaneously for the two facts that beliefs (a) depend on minds for their underscore existence underscore, (b) do not depend on minds for their underscore truth underscore.

column2: We may restate our theory as follows: If we take such a belief as 'Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio', we will call Desdemona and Cassio the _object-terms_, and loving the _object-relation_.
column3: We may restate our theory as follows: If we take such a belief as 'Othello believes that Desdemona loves Cassio', we will call Desdemona and Cassio the underscore object terms underscore, and loving the underscore object relation underscore.

column2: If there is a complex unity 'Desdemona's love for Cassio', consisting of the object-terms related by the object-relation in the same order as they have in the belief, then this complex unity is called the _fact corresponding to the belief_.
column3: If there is a complex unity 'Desdemona's love for Cassio', consisting of the object terms related by the object relation in the same order as they have in the belief, then this complex unity is called the underscore fact corresponding to the belief underscore.

column2: Thus a belief is true when there is a corresponding fact, and is false when there is no corresponding fact.
column3: Thus a belief is true when there is a corresponding fact, and is false when there is no corresponding fact.

column2: It will be seen that minds do not _create_ truth or falsehood.
column3: It will be seen that minds do not underscore create underscore truth or falsehood.

column2: They create beliefs, but when once the beliefs are created, the mind cannot make them true or false, except in the special case where they concern future things which are within the power of the person believing, such as catching trains.
column3: They create beliefs, but when once the beliefs are created, the mind cannot make them true or false, except in the special case where they concern future things which are within the power of the person believing, such as catching trains.

column2: What makes a belief true is a _fact_, and this fact does not (except in exceptional cases) in any way involve the mind of the person who has the belief.
column3: What makes a belief true is a underscore fact underscore, and this fact does not (except in exceptional cases) in any way involve the mind of the person who has the belief.

column2: Having now decided what we _mean_ by truth and falsehood, we have next to consider what ways there are of knowing whether this or that belief is true or false.
column3: Having now decided what we underscore mean underscore by truth and falsehood, we have next to consider what ways there are of knowing whether this or that belief is true or false.

column2: This consideration will occupy the next chapter.
column3: This consideration will occupy the next chapter.
